results.title: Bill Brandt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Master Photographers Series”.
In this rare insight, Brandt shows some of his favourite photographs among them pictures of Paris in the 1920s, his compassionate scenes of Britain in the Depression, his Nudes and many distinguished portraits.

results.title: Alfred Eisenstaedt
results.creator_credit: Peter Adam and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Master Photographers Series”.
Looks at the life and work of former ‘Life’ magazine photographer Alfred Eisenstaedt. Concentrates on portraits of celebrities from 1929 to the present.

results.title: Filmstruck Series
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Going It Alone
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Filmmaking has never really been studio based. John Baxter, well known Australian film historian and cinema critic, interviews some of the independents. He also takes a look at the Disney animation studio in Burbank, as well as showing us rare footage of a surrealist “Snow White” starring Betty Boop. this program is the final episode in the “Filmstruck” series which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: The Best Remaining Seats
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
John Baxter, well known Australian historian and cinema critic, examines the fall of the great cinema houses, how the Hollywood industry built them and Hollywood acted as a magnet for both talent and money. Charlie Chaplin’s career is also analysed. This episode is one of the “Filmstruck” series which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Switzerland/Texas
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Filming in Australia has been described as “Switzerland wanting to go to Texas”. In this program, John Baxter, well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, looks at the state of the Australian film industry. This is part five of a ten part documentary “Filmstruck” which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: You Can't Say That
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Oh! The problems of censorship! John Baxter shows, from the days of seemingly innocuous material such as the Keystone Cops to the present, that there have been recurrent problems with Censorship boards. This program, part of a ten part documentary, Filmstruck, considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: The Blink of an eye
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
This is part two of “Filmstruck”, a series hosted by the well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, John Baxter, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience. In this episode, John Baxter takes a closer look at cinema stunts and the men that performed them, from early Tom Mix to Mad Max 2.

results.title: Funny Business
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Bette Davis' eyes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
What makes a star? Clips from a host of films look at the legendary stars - Sarah Bernhardt, Shirley Temple, Joan Crawford, Errol Flynn and Bette Davis. This program is episode seven in the ten part documentary, “Filmstruck”, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.
